Ethylene oligomerization is an important step for upgrading light olefins to liquid fuels or value-added chemicals such as butene monomers. Ethylene oligomerization catalyzed by mono-Ni substituted polyoxometalate (POM) catalysts is promising due to the observed selectivity toward linear butene products and stability of these well-defined materials. In this work, two approaches to tailor the catalytic properties of isolated Ni sites in POMs were experimentally tested, both of which perturbed the surrounding molecular environment of the active sites. First, structural modifications were performed to alter the size of the polyoxometalates, evaluating between Wells-Dawson and Keggin structures while maintaining the same elemental components. When comparing these two structures, it was observed that the Ni active sites were kinetically independent from the effect of POM size, even when the POM consisted of the same elements. This was evidenced by the identical product distributions and kinetic parameters observed with both structures. However, a localized kinetic effect was observed when Keggin POM structures containing different internal heteroatoms (e.g, P, Si, Al) were included in close proximity to the Ni active site. Specifically, a notable periodic trend was observed between the electronegativity of internal heteroatoms and the measured apparent activation energy for the catalyzed ethylene coupling reaction to butene. Graphical Abstract The size and composition of Ni-modified polyoxometalates can be varied significantly through synthetic approaches. For ethylene oligomerization, the size of the POM (Wells-Dawson vs. Keggin) did not influence the kinetic behavior of the Ni, but the variation in internal heteroatom dramatically influences the activation barrier. ga1 Keywords Dimerization Shale gas Polyoxometalate Nickel Earth abundant Fuels Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Olefin oligomerization is an important step to produce liquid fuels or valued-added chemicals such as linear alpha olefins.[1–19] Light olefin oligomerization by heterogeneous catalysis has been widely investigated as a solution to address current issues with homogeneous systems by avoiding complicated separation processes and an additional activation step by pyrophoric methyl-aluminoxane co-catalysts. [1,20,21] Nickel-based solid catalysts with isolated nickel active sites are promising alternatives for heterogeneous light olefin oligomerization. Prime examples include Ni2+ exchanged aluminosilicates (e.g. micro-mesoporous materials) and Ni (II) modified metal organic frameworks (MOFs) containing well-defined structures.[22–25] Despite having robust porous structures, Ni2+ exchanged aluminosilicates have been speculated to suffer from deactivation caused by mobility of Ni after olefin adsorption.[11,18,26,27] Alternatively, Ni (II) modified MOF catalysts selectively yield linear alpha olefins, but their low thermal stability often prevents them from being operated at elevated temperatures [28]. Wells-Dawson polyoxometalates (POM-WD) can be utilized as a molecular level platform to isolate Ni active sites for light olefin oligomerization.[29] Further, this catalyst was shown to have similar kinetic parameters to other Ni active sites supported on zeolites and MOFs without irreversible deactivation after undergoing multiple thermal regeneration cycles.[29] Magazova et al. recently reported the use of this catalyst for propylene oligomerization.[30] Ni isolated POM-WD showed better selectivity toward linear dimeric hexene species compared to the benchmark potassium poisoned Ni2+ exchanged beta zeolites (BEA) due to lack of Brønsted acid-induced side reactions.[30] In a separate study, Magazova et al. showed Ni POM-WD catalysts were resistant to hydrogen and methane through uncompromised propene dimerization rates and product distribution of Ni-P2W17-WD catalysts, although it was observed that carbon monoxide competitively adsorbed on active sites to reduce overall olefin coupling rates.[31]. Polyoxometalates can be modified in various ways to alter their catalytic behavior.[32–40] Macht et al. investigated the kinetic effects of elemental changes within Keggin-type polyoxometalate structures.[35,36,38] Their work demonstrated that the deprotonation energies of Keggin heteropoly acid (HPA) catalysts were strongly influenced by internal heteroatoms such as P, Si, Al, and Co.[35–38] Increased deprotonation energy resulted in higher activation barriers for three different acid-catalyzed reactions, including hexane isomerization and 2-butanol elimination.[35–38] Wilke et al. explored the effect of adjusting the species (e.g. Na+, Mg2+, Cu2+, and Al3+) and concentration of counter cations in a Keggin polyoxometalate on its acidic properties.[41,42] Their findings revealed that the turnover frequencies of methanol dehydration and oxidation were largely dependent on the concentration of acid sites, rather than the type of counter cations used.[41,42] In addition, Choi et al. investigated the modification of redox properties by substituting different transition metal ions on the lacunary sites of POM-WD catalysts and internal heteroatoms of Keggin HPA.[39,40,43] Their research revealed that the reduction potential of POM catalysts was influenced by the incorporation of different substituted transition metal ions or internal heteroatoms.[39,40,43] For instance, on the lacunary defects of POM structures, different transition metals (Mn > Co > Ni > Zn) were substituted to compare the catalytic performance of each transition metal-substituted POM catalyst.[39,40,43] POM catalysts containing transition metal ions with higher reduction potential produced higher yields of oxidation products.[39,40,43] Previous investigations have focused on the changes in the Brønsted acidity resulting from the use of various internal heteroatoms (P, Si, Al) in HPA catalysts.[32–38] It has also been reported that substituted transition metal ions perturb the electronic properties of the overall POM anion structures and such perturbations result in kinetic changes for redox chemistry.[39,40,43] However, the effect of internal heteroatoms (P, Si, Al) on the kinetic properties of substituted transition metal active sites for olefin oligomerization has not been investigated to our knowledge. As noted above, Wells-Dawson (POM-WD) and Keggin (POM-KG) polyoxometalate structures are perhaps the two most studied polyoxometalate structures in the field of chemistry and biochemistry based on the number of publications (>800 publications). These two structures can be synthesized by relatively simple procedures, which likely motivates the attention placed on these materials.[39,40,43–45] As seen in Fig. 1a, the anion structure of Wells-Dawson consists of two internal heteroatoms surrounded by 18 addenda metal oxides. For the Wells-Dawson structure, phosphorous and tungsten are the most common internal heteroatoms and addenda metals, respectively. The anion structure of Wells-Dawson phosphor-tungstate is crystallized with counter cations such as potassium. The Keggin structure is a smaller version of the Wells-Dawson structure which consists of one internal heteroatom with 12 addenda metal oxides (Fig. 1b). The Keggin structure can also be synthesized with the same constituent elements (e.g. K, P, W, O) of Wells-Dawson phosphor-tungstates. While maintaining similar elemental composition, the length of Keggin structure (10Å) is only 66% of Wells-Dawson structure (15Å). Both Keggin and Wells Dawson structures can be modified to form a lacunary defect which is created by partial removal of one of each tungsten and oxygen atoms. On these lacunary defects, transition metal ions can be substituted to somewhat retain the original structures. Since similar types of lacunary defects can be formed on both of Wells-Dawson and Keggin phosphor-tungstates with the same constituent elements, they are suitable structures to study how the size of the site bearing POM structure affects the kinetic behavior of the isolated Ni active sites. In this study, we present an experimental approach that investigates how the surroundings of Ni-substituted polyoxometalates affect isolated single Ni sites. First, we modified the size of the host polyoxometalate structures. Specifically, we isolated Ni sites on the lacunary defects of both Wells-Dawson and Keggin structures, which consisted of the same elements (such as K, P, W). This allowed us to observe the kinetic influence caused by the size difference of the polyoxometalates (POMs). Alternatively, compositionally induced kinetic effects were studied by using Keggin POM catalysts with three different internal heteroatoms (P, Si, Al). The kinetic parameters and product distributions from catalytic, low conversion ethylene oligomerization were analyzed and compared. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Catalysts The synthesis of K5PW11O39·Ni2+ (Ni-PW11-KG) was done by following previously reported synthesis method as noted in the subsequent steps.[40] First, H3PW12O40 was dissolved in deionized water and ion-exchanged with 1 g of KCl. Keggin phospho-tungstate derivative material with lacunary defects was synthesized by adjusting pH to 5–5.5 with addition of 1 M KHCO3 solution under vigorous stirring. Clear solution was obtained from as-prepared solution with white precipitates by vacuum filtration via celite pad. After overnight cooling of collected clear solution at 2–3 ℃ overnight, K7PW11O39 crystals were gathered by vacuum filtration via medium frits. Stoichiometrically equal amount of as-synthesized K7PW11O39 and Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O were dissolved in de-ionized water separately. Aqueous Ni(NO3)2 was added dropwise to K7PW11O39 solution while being vigorously stirred. After the addition, the yellow-green solution was left under vigorous stirring for 1 h. The mixture of methanol and ethanol with 1:1 ratio was added to precipitate K5PW11O39·Ni2+ (Ni-PW11-KG) crystals and obtained precipitates were collected by vacuum filtration via fine frits. Following the previous work of Ma et al., lacunary Keggin silico-tungstate, K8SiW11O39 was made via a one-pot synthesis approach.[46] Sodium metasilicate was dissolved in deionized water separately from sodium-tungstate solution which was dissolved in deionized water and 12 M HCl. After complete dissolution, two aqueous solutions of sodium metasilicate and sodium tungstate were mixed. The pH of this solution was adjusted from 8 to 5 by adding 12 M HCl. Then, crude product was obtained by adding excess KCl and obtained precipitates were recrystallized for purification. As-synthesized K8SiW11O39 crystals were dissolved in deionized water and stoichiometric among of Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O was added to metallate lacunary defects. Crude products of K6SiW11O39·Ni2+ were precipitated by KCl addition and subsequent vacuum filtration. The crystals of K6SiW11O39·Ni2+ were obtained after being purified via recrystallization. Ni substituted Keggin alumino-tungstates were synthesized by a reported multi-step approach.[47] First, H5AlW12O40 was synthesized by dissolution of sodium tungstate and aluminum chloride under acidic aqueous solution and subsequent acidification by addition of sulfuric acid to nearly pH of 0. The pH level of the as-prepared H5AlW12O40 solution was adjusted by adding 1 M potassium carbonate solution to pH of 8 to form lacunary defects. Precipitates obtained after potassium carbonate addition were recrystallized for purification. Then, collected crystals of K9AlW11O39 were metalated with stoichiometric amount of Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O in aqueous solution. After Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O was added, the resulting cloudy mixture was vacuum filtered through a celite bed. Crystals of K7AlW11O39·Ni2+ were obtained from the clear solution at 2–3 oC. SBA-15 was synthesized by following synthetic procedures which was previously reported.[48,49] First, 18 g of P 123 EO-PO-EO block copolymer was dissolved in 561 g of deionized water with 99.5 g of 12 M HCl and left under vigorous stirring overnight. After complete dissolution of block copolymer in acidic aqueous solution, 39.8 g of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) was mixed while being stirred at room temperature for 5 min. Then, the prepared precursor was transferred to an oven which was preheated at 35 °C and aged for 20 h at the same temperature. Previously aged precursor solution was precipitated at 80 °C for 24 h. Precipitates of SBA-15 were gathered by vacuum filtration and washed with 1.5 L of deionized water. Filtered precipitates were dried at 60 °C overnight and calcined at 550 ℃ for 6 h. Calcined SBA-15 sample was further dried by heating at 200 ℃ under vacuum and stored inside N2 glove box. An equivalent amount of NiXW11-KG for each desired weight loadings was dissolved in 1.6 ml/g of deionized water and impregnated on as-synthesized SBA-15 via incipient wetness method. Then, immobilized Ni-XW11-KG samples were dried at 100 °C overnight. 2.2 Characterization of Catalysts Phosphorous-31 Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (31P NMR) spectra of synthesized Keggin phosphor-tungstate derivative materials were collected by Bruker AVANCE III HD 500. Solution 31P NMR samples were prepared by dissolving desired phosphor-tungstate samples in the mixture with the 9:1 ratio of deionized water and D2O prior to measurement. Due to the synthetic difficulty of Ni-PW11-KG to grow a suitable single crystal for x-ray crystallography, it was ion-exchanged with CsCl to obtain an x-ray diffraction pattern. Full molecular structures of Ni-XW11-KG (X = P, Si and Al) were obtained via single crystal x-ray diffraction. X-ray diffraction pattern of collected single crystals was obtained by using Bruker APEX-II diffractometer using a combination of ω- and φ-scans of 0.5°. Porosity of SBA-15 and immobilized Keggin polyoxometalate/SBA-15 materials was evaluated via Nitrogen Physisorption using Quantachrome 2200e. Prior to the analysis, samples were subjected to vacuum degassing at 200 ℃. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was done by using PHI 5000 Versa Probe II which has a monochromatic Kα x-ray source. The measurement was done under x-ray with power and voltage of 25 W and 15 kV with resolution of 0.1 eV. The obtained spectra of binding energy were shifted to the reference peak of C1s at 284.5 eV. 2.3 Catalytic Ethylene Oligomerization Gas phase ethylene oligomerization experiments were conducted with ¼ inch stainless steel reactor which was packed with 30–200 mg of sieved catalysts diluted by silica gel particles (60–100 mesh size). Catalysts were pretreated under flowing helium (Airgas UHP300) for 12 h at 300 ℃ at atmospheric pressure and cooled down to reaction temperatures. Once the reaction temperatures were reached, feed streams which were composed of desired light olefin and helium were exposed to the catalyst bed at set pressure regions. Product stream was analyzed by SRI 8610 GC FID starting 10 min after the feed stream was introduced. An injection to GC-FID was conducted every 35 min. Ethylene conversion and product selectivity were calculated by following other published works on ethylene oligomerization.[50–52] The moles of fed ethylene were determined by summing detected moles of ethylene and product species from the product stream. The sum of products were divided by the fed ethylene to calculate ethylene conversion. The product selectivity was measured by dividing the detected moles of total products. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Localized Kinetic Effect by Structural Modification of POM Catalysts The structures of the synthesized POMs were verified by 31P NMR. A single 31P NMR peak at 13 ppm was observed with POM-WD, as reported in literature (Fig. S1a).[29] Lacunary sites were created by controlling the pH of the aqueous POM-WD solution to 8, where a tungsten and an oxygen atom are removed from tri-capping tungsten oxides of the Wells-Dawson structure. Once lacunary sites were formed, the two internal phosphates experience different local bonding environments, which results in two 31P NMR peaks at − 7.5 ppm and − 14 ppm (Fig. S1a).[29] To substitute a Ni site on lacunary defect of POM-WD, a stoichiometric amount of Ni2+ ions were added to the lacunary POM-WD solution. The complete metalation of these sites was confirmed through the drastic shift and broadening of a 31P NMR peak responsible for the internal phosphate which is closer to the lacunary defect. This 31P NMR peak at − 7.5 ppm is shifted to 200–250 ppm and broadened due to incorporation of paramagnetic Ni2+ ion (Fig. S1a).[29]. Because protonated Keggin phosphor-tungstic acid is commercially available, we began the synthesis by exchanging cations with potassium chloride in deionized water. Crystals of lacunary POM-KG were precipitated after appropriately adjusting the pH. The lacunary POM-KG structure was confirmed through observation of a single 31P NMR peak at − 11.9 ppm (Fig. S1b).[40,43,53] Lacunary sites of POM-KG were metalated with a stoichiometric amount of Ni(NO3)2. The complete substitution of Ni sites on lacunary defects was shown by the drastic shift and broadening of the peak at − 11.9–470 ppm due to introduction of external paramagnetic Ni2+ ion to the anion structure of POM-KG (Fig. S1b).[40,53]. The full structures of Ni substituted Keggin and Wells-Dawson phosphor-tungstate were solved based on single crystal x-ray diffraction patterns (Fig. S2a and b). Based on crystallographic data, representative images for anionic structures of Ni-substituted Keggin and Wells-Dawson phosphor-tungstate are depicted in Fig. 2. Within the anion structure of Ni-P2W17-WD, a Ni site is incorporated to a lacunary defect located in the top capping region of Wells-Dawson structure.[29] Except for the top tri-capping tungsten oxides which a Ni site was substituted, the remaining portion of the Wells-Dawson structure was preserved (Fig. 2a). Similarly, Ni-PW11-KG anion structure also bears a single Ni site on its lacunary defect (Fig. 2b). Along with a substituted Ni site, 11 tungsten oxides surrounded an internal phosphate (Fig. 2b). Ni substituted Wells-Dawson and Keggin phosphor-tungstates are referred to as Ni-P2W17-WD and Ni-PW11-KG based on the elemental composition of anion structures. As we previously reported, Ni substituted Wells-Dawson POMs are not active in the form of bulk crystals due to the inhibited access of Ni sites.[29] To ensure site accessibility, both of Ni-P2W17-WD and Ni-PW11-KG structures were dispersed throughout the mesopores of high surface area SBA-15. The textural properties of SBA-15 and supported POM catalysts were determined by N2 physisorption and presented in Table S1. After dispersion of the POMs on SBA-15, the possible kinetic consequences induced by the size difference between Wells-Dawson and Keggin was assessed. We hypothesized that because the primary difference between Ni-P2W17-WD and Ni-PW11-KG related to the size of the single clusters, the kinetic behavior of the two Ni-modified structures should be similar. For this comparison, kinetic assessment was carried out in the low conversion regime where the initial dimerization event could be properly captured. Due to this reason, kinetic parameters such as dimer selectivity, dependence on ethylene partial pressure, and apparent activation energies were measured below 1% ethylene conversion ( Fig. 3). In Fig. 3a, butene selectivity of both Ni-P2W17-WD and Ni-PW11-KG within 0.1–0.4% ethylene conversion was measured from a single time on stream ethylene dimerization experiment done at 200 ℃ and 20.2 bar. Multiple data points of product selectivity at different ethylene conversion values were collected from a single run of ethylene oligomerization due to the deactivation occurring with time on stream. An overlapping linear trend of 1-butene and trans/cis-2-butene selectivity at approximately 67%, 18% and 12% was observed from both Ni-PW11-KG and Ni-P2W17-WD catalysts. This converging product selectivity of Ni-P2W17-WD and Ni-PW11-KG indicates that Ni sites catalytically behave in very similar manner. The rate dependence on the ethylene partial pressure with Ni-PW11-KG was measured within the ethylene partial pressure range of 0.62–3.2 bar. In Fig. 3b, Ni-PW11-KG yielded a second order ethylene pressure dependence as did NiP2W17-WD in our previous work.[29] A second order dependence on ethylene partial pressure could be rationalized when the coupling event occurs between a gaseous ethylene molecule and adsorbed ethylene surface species under dilute ethylene concentration.[29,54,55] Further, this second order dependency of Ni-PW11-KG suggests that the coupling surface reaction occurs very similarly to Ni-P2W17-WD.[29] The apparent activation energy of Ni-PW11-KG for ethylene oligomerization was measured and also compared to that of Ni-P2W17-WD. The apparent Ea over Ni-PW11-KG was measured as 42 ± 5 kJ/mol (Fig. 3c), which is nearly identical to that of Ni-P2W17-WD (41 ± 4 kJ/mol),[29] and further suggests ethylene dimerization occurs on Ni active sites independent of the size of site bearing POM entity. To investigate the influence of POM size on the production of heavy oligomers (C6 +), we compared the oligomer product distribution between Ni-PW11-KG and Ni-P2W17-WD catalysts at identical ethylene conversions ( Fig. 4). A single time-on-stream experiment was conducted to measure ethylene conversion and oligomer selectivity, focusing on relatively high ethylene conversion values (>20%). From these experiments, we observed nearly identical selectivity to dimer and heavier oligomers with both catalysts (Fig. 4). This indicates that the size variation of the polyoxometalate host did not significantly impact the selectivity towards these specific oligomer products. Subsequent chain growth reactions after initial dimerization were found to occur similarly on Ni-PW11-KG and Ni-P2W17-WD. This result was further supported through x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). As shown in Fig. S3 a and b, Ni 2p 3/2 binding energy of Ni-P2W17-WD and Ni-PW11-KG was measured as 856.3 eV and 856.4 eV, respectively. The XPS binding energy values of these two Ni-POM catalysts were within the resolution limit (0.1 eV). These results indicate that the kinetic and electronic parameters of the Ni active sites were highly similar between the Ni-modified Wells-Dawson and Ni-modified Keggin structures, suggesting the size of the POM does not significantly influence the properties of the Ni active sites when the POMs are comprised of the same elements. 3.2 Localized Kinetic Effect by Compositional Modification of POM Catalysts To investigate the kinetic effects induced by variations in composition on substituted Ni active sites, modifications to the polyoxometalate (POM) structure were necessary. In this study, we expanded our analysis by synthesizing two additional Keggin polyoxometalates, introducing Si and Al as new internal heteroatoms alongside P, while keeping the addenda tungsten oxides unchanged. This approach allowed us to determine whether a periodic trend in the internal heteroatoms impacts the kinetic behavior of Ni-substituted Keggin POM catalysts. Si and Al were specifically selected as new internal heteroatoms for this analysis. To create lacunary defects, the pH was carefully controlled under mildly basic conditions. Subsequently, lacunary Keggin polyoxometalate crystals with each internal heteroatom (Si or Al) were obtained through precipitation and recrystallization processes. Ni active sites were substituted on the lacunary defects, and anionic structures of these two Ni substituted Keggin POM catalysts (Ni-SiW11-KG and Ni-AlW11-KG) were solved via single crystal x-ray diffraction patterns (Fig. S2 c and d). Single Ni sites were incorporated within the anionic structure of Keggin polyoxometalate by replacing one of 12 WO sites. It was also confirmed that all three of the solved structures contain tetrahedral oxide of internal heteroatoms (e.g. P, Si, Al) surrounded by 11 tungsten oxides ( Fig. 5). To identify possible compositional effects of the Keggin polyoxometalate (POM), we analyzed the initial dimeric product distribution at conversions below 0.2%, where trimeric products were negligible. Fig. 6 presents the selectivity to different butene species for Ni-XW11-KG catalysts with three distinct internal heteroatoms (X = P, Si, and Al) at 200 °C and 6 bar. In the time-on-stream ethylene dimerization experiments, the 1-butene/2-butene ratios were determined for the three Ni-POM-KG catalysts and compared. Under this relatively dilute ethylene pressure regime, less 1-butene is typically observed, and this regime was specifically chosen to provide clear differences in the dimeric product distribution. Interestingly, the ratio of 1-butene to 2-butene remained nearly unchanged when compared at the same ethylene conversion (Fig. 6). This observation suggests that the initial dimerization process on the Ni active sites occurs similarly regardless of the internal heteroatom present in the catalyst. This finding is consistent with the work of Meloni et al., who demonstrated that the 1-butene/2-butene ratio of Ni2 + -exchanged Beta was independent of the framework heteroatom (Al, Fe, and Ga) within the zeolite.[56] They observed that the overall ethylene consumption rate was perturbed due to the change in Brønsted acidity of the zeolite.[56] However, the ratio between 1-butene and 2-butene was nearly identical because the Ni2 + sites follow the Cossee-Arlman mechanism as opposed to the metallocycle mechanism which favors 1-butene formation.[[56] Similarly, Sarazen et al. reported that the density functional theory (DFT) calculated deprotonation enthalpies of POM-KG with different heteroatoms (P, Si, Al) are invariant toward the formation of secondary propoxide species during propene oligomerization.[57] The overlapping ratio of 1-butene to cis/trans-2-butenes observed in our study further supports the notion that the initial dimerization step on Ni active sites is not significantly influenced by the specific internal heteroatom present in the catalyst. [56]. The energy barriers for ethylene oligomerization were measured and evaluated for the three Ni-XW11-KG catalysts, as shown in Fig. 7. As seen in Fig. 7a and b, Ni-SiW11-KG exhibited an apparent activation energy of 56 ± 6 kJ/mol, while Ni-AlW11-KG was measured at 80 ± 2 kJ/mol. As provided previously in Fig. 3c, the apparent activation energy increased from P (42 ± 5 kJ/mol; Fig. 3c) to Al (i.e., Al > Si > P), indicating that the energy barrier increases with the electronegativity of the internal heteroatom. Despite the similar dimeric product distribution observed among the Ni-XW11-KG (X = P, Si, and Al) catalysts, the interaction between the substituted Ni active sites and the internal heteroatom influences the barrier of the coupling reaction. Janik et al. previously reported that the deprotonation energy of a proton ionically bound to the Keggin heteropolyacid decreases with a periodic trend in electronegativity of the internal heteroatom.[37] The observed change in the electronegativity of the internal heteroatom leads to significant variations in the adsorption energy and activation barrier, thereby influencing the preferred reaction pathway for acid-catalyzed reactions. This electronic effect and subsequent kinetic perturbation were also observed on Ni active sites within Keggin polyoxometalates with different elemental compositions. These findings indicate that the interaction between Ni and the internal heteroatom induces a localized kinetic effect on the Ni active sites. Thus, the specific composition and electronic environment surrounding the Ni sites play a crucial role in governing their catalytic behavior. To evaluate the electronic differences of the substituted Ni sites in Ni-XW11-KG catalysts (where X = P, Si, and Al), we conducted an analysis of the Ni 2p 3/2 binding energy using XPS to examine the electronic states and characteristics of the Ni atoms present in the catalysts. As seen in Fig. S3 b-d, binding energies for Ni 2p 3/2 were measured to increase from 856.4 eV (Ni-PW11-KG), 856.0 eV (Ni-SiW11-KG) and to 855.7 eV (Ni-AlW11-KG). Lower Ni binding energies in the XPS analysis indicate a higher electron density of the Ni sites. Based on this observation, we correlated the trend in apparent activation energy among the three Ni-XW11-KG catalysts with electronegativity. The Allred-Rochow electronegativity values for the internal heteroatoms (P, Si, and Al) was compared with the Ni electron density, which was represented by the Ni 2p 3/2 binding energy obtained from XPS measurements. As shown in Fig. 8a, the Ni 2p 3/2 binding energy of each Keggin polyoxometalate increases as the electronegativity of the internal heteroatom increases. This indicates that the electron density is being removed from the Ni sites, leading to an increase in the binding energy of the valence electrons. This trend is consistent with findings from Zhang et al., who investigated homogeneous Ni complexes with various organic ligands. Their study also observed a similar correlation between the binding energy of Ni and the electron-donating or electron-withdrawing nature of the ligands.[58] Also reported by Zhang et al.,[58] a decrease in the net charge on Ni was observed when it was surrounded by less electronegative ligands. This decrease in net charge led to a higher energy barrier for ethylene insertion.[58] Consistently, in our study, we also observed an increase in the apparent activation barrier as the electronegativity of the internal heteroatom decreased (Fig. 8b). This trend aligns with a coordination-insertion mechanism, further supporting the influence of the electronegativity of the internal heteroatom on the kinetic behavior of the system. 3.3 Mechanistic Insights for Ethylene Oligomerization on Ni-POM Catalysts Regardless of the structural modifications implemented in the POM platforms, the product streams consistently exhibited the same butene species. The presence of three linear butene species, namely 1-butene, cis-2-butene, and trans-2-butene, suggests that these are the primary products of dimerization, following the Cossee-Arlman mechanism ( Fig. 9).[16,26,54,55,59,60] The ethylene dimerization cycle for the Cossee-Arlman mechanism typically starts with the adsorption of ethylene on Ni active sites.[26,59] The formed Ni-ethyl species undergo a chain growth reaction with gaseous ethylene inserted into the complex to form a Ni-butyl surface species (Fig. 9).[26,59] Then, this formed complex proceeds through β-elimination to desorb 1-butene from the active site.[26,59] It is possible that the formed 1-butene can undergo parallel isomerization on Ni sites to produce linear internal cis/trans-2-butenes.[26,59] Based on same product distribution from all of the studied Ni-POM catalysts in this work, there appears to be no structural or compositional effect on the mechanism for ethylene dimerization. 4 Conclusion Here, we presented the effects of POM size (Wells-Dawson vs. Keggin) and internal heteroatom (P, Si, Al) of Keggin structures on the oligomerization behavior of Ni-modified POMs. We report the kinetic independence of Ni sites from the size of POM structures, indicating that the size of the POM does not significantly affect the catalytic activity of the Ni sites. We observed localized kinetic effects by varying the internal heteroatom (P, Si, Al) on Ni sites within the POM structures. This suggests that the composition of the POM at the atomic level can influence the kinetic properties of the Ni active sites. Our study provides mechanistic insights into the ethylene dimerization reaction on Ni-POM catalysts, shedding light on the fundamental processes and reaction pathways involved. Taken together, these findings contribute to a better understanding of the relationship between the structure of polyoxometalates, the properties of isolated Ni active sites, and their catalytic behavior in alkene dimerization reactions. coredata.dc:description: Ethylene oligomerization is an important step for upgrading light olefins to liquid fuels or value-added chemicals such as butene monomers. Ethylene oligomerization catalyzed by mono-Ni substituted polyoxometalate (POM) catalysts is promising due to the observed selectivity toward linear butene products and stability of these well-defined materials. In this work, two approaches to tailor the catalytic properties of isolated Ni sites in POMs were experimentally tested, both of which perturbed the surrounding molecular environment of the active sites. First, structural modifications were performed to alter the size of the polyoxometalates, evaluating between Wells-Dawson and Keggin structures while maintaining the same elemental components. When comparing these two structures, it was observed that the Ni active sites were kinetically independent from the effect of POM size, even when the POM consisted of the same elements. This was evidenced by the identical product distributions and kinetic parameters observed with both structures. However, a localized kinetic effect was observed when Keggin POM structures containing different internal heteroatoms (e.g, P, Si, Al) were included in close proximity to the Ni active site. Specifically, a notable periodic trend was observed between the electronegativity of internal heteroatoms and the measured apparent activation energy for the catalyzed ethylene coupling reaction to butene.
coredata.dc:title: Localized structural and compositional effects on the kinetic performance of Ni-modified polyoxometalate catalysts for ethylene oligomerization
